awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: Collaborative Research: Exploring a Robust Quantum Cryptography Protocol for Securing Optical Burst Switching Networks
awd_abstract_narration: This proposal explores a robust quantum cryptography protocol for securing optical burst switching (OBS) networks, providing a means to make the OBS-based future Internet trustworthy from the ground up. Since the OBS network has a one-to-one correspondence between the header and its associated burst, the same relationship can be exploited for encryption. The quantum-based methodology makes it possible to distribute keys securely so that each burst is encrypted and decrypted with a unique key. As the well-known BB84 quantum cryptography protocol is susceptible to siphoning attacks on the multiple photons emitted by practical sources, we use a new 3-stage quantum cryptography protocol which is immune to such siphoning attacks, for it is based on random rotations of the polarization vector. The new 3-stage quantum cryptography protocol allows practical photon sources to be used in the quantum key exchange, making it feasible to extend quantum cryptography services beyond trusted routers. The 3-stage all quantum protocol is being investigated for its performance in different noise situations for different key generation rates. The implementation of the protocol uses quantum phase modulation rather than polarization modulation which is not stable in the long transmission over fiber. The research conducted in this proposal includes the design of an integrated secure router and investigation of quantum cryptography protocols for specific services. This research will be verified on a reconfigurable optical burst switching test bed.

Intellectual Merit:  

Classical implementations of cryptography are only computationally secure. As computing power increases, classical cryptography and key management schemes based on computational complexity become increasingly susceptible to brute force and cryptanalytic attacks. The security of quantum cryptography is based on the inherent uncertainty in quantum phenomena and quantum-secured information cannot be deciphered by quantum computers. Quantum cryptography today is largely realized as Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) which exchanges keys at a fast rate between a sender and a receiver using conventional cryptography. This project is focused on the development of the three-stage quantum cryptography protocol that addresses the major shortcoming of the industry-standard BB84 protocol which is limited to no more than a single photon per time slot. This
investigation offers solutions for use in a wide variety of applications that
require extremely high level of security.

An experimental lab realization of the three-stage protocol has been accomplished as part of this project. A major achievement was the successful replacement of the mechanical components, responsible for providing unitary transformation to the optical beam, by an electromechanical device. Such a device can apply polarization modulation of the optical beam using a variable voltage generator. This has led to the speedup of data transfer by a couple of orders of magnitude.

This project has provided a practical multi-photon tolerant quantum cryptography approach to overcome the limitation of existing single-photon approaches. It thus has the potential to increase the distance and the speed of quantum communication. A major attribute of this investigation has been to show that the three-stage protocol is not constrained by the requirement of no more than a single photon per time-slot. A theoretical framework for this research has also been developed. A braided version of the three-stage algorithm has been implemented at the University of Oklahoma. New theoretical results have been obtained on how to use the quantum cryptography protocols in the piggy bank mode.

A quantum burst control protocol has been devised to take advantage of the intrinsic timing control of the optical burst network and its ability to pass quantum data through a dedicated passive quantum optical path. The timing
synchronization issue has been investigated to take into account the fact that
multiple photons traversing the fiber may go through different rotation
operators for high speed transmission.

A major outcome has been extending the multi-stage protocol to provide secure communication in the fast evolving wireless and cellular communication. The research addressed the secure transfer of keys to encrypt information transferred over the WiFi network or the cellular network using a variety of protocols, e.g., the WiMax and LTE protocols.

The focus on polarization has been a direct result of the experience gained as part of this project. Three invention disclosures were filed, followed by the filing of utility patents at the University of Oklahoma, and one patent application was filed at the University of Houston. One of the Utility patent applications “Optical Cryptography Systems and Methods”, filed on behalf of the Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma has been allowed on October 7, 2015, as published on the United States Patent Office website. The formal notification of acceptance is expected to follow within two weeks of this date.
